children.name: when a place has people living in it
inhabited
children.definition: an area of land or a building that is inhabited has people living in it:
examples: Only two of the islands are inhabited.
This tiny town has been an inhabited area for over 3,000 years.

children.name: occupied
children.definition: a building or room that is occupied has people living in it:
examples: None of the flats is occupied - they’ve only just been built.

children.name: populated
children.definition: with people living there:
examples: Bears are appearing more and more frequently in populated areas
densely/heavily populatedhaving many people
The north-east has always been more densely populated than the rest of the country.
thinly/sparsely populatedhaving few people
French Guiana is a sparsely populated wilderness.

children.name: residential area
children.definition: an area where there are houses where people live: khu dân cư
examples: The museum is about 6 blocks from downtown in a quiet residential area.
London’s main airport is surrounded by densely populated residential areas.

children.name: human habitation
children.definition: use this about a place that humans live in or have lived in in the past: nơi cư trú của con người
examples: The only sign of human habitation was a charred area where there had once been a fire.

children.name: when you live in the same house as sb else
live with
children.definition: For two months I lived with a French family in Paris to improve my French.
examples: What’s the name of the guy you live with?
We’ve been trying to persuade Jack’s elderly mother to come and live with us.

children.name: share a house/ apartment/ room/ flat with
children.definition: to live with sb who isnota member ofyourfamilyandnotyoursexualpartner:

children.name: My brother shares a house with four other students
examples: Kim and I shared an apartment when I first moved to L.A.

children.name: room with
children.definition: US to live in the sameroomas sbatcollege: ở cùng phòng, trọ cùng phòng
examples: Do you remember Diane? I roomed with her at college.
Have you decided who you’re going to room with next year?
At college he roomswiththis guy from Nebraska.

children.name: suitable for people to live in or not
habitable
children.definition: a building or area of land that is habitable is suitable for people to live in, for example because it is clean enough, warm enough, safe enough etc:
examples: There are already plans to renovate the buildings and make them habitable.
Japan is mostly mountainous and has a only a relatively narrow strip of habitable land along the coasts.

children.name: fit to live in
children.definition: if a building is fit to live in, it is in a suitable condition for people to live in it:
examples: As soon as the farm was fit to live in, we moved all our things there.

children.name: not be fit to live innot in a suitable condition for people to live in
examples: The first apartment we looked at just wasn’t fit to live in.

children.name: uninhabitable
children.definition: not suitable for living in or on:
examples: A nuclear accident would make the whole region uninhabitable.
Twenty of the houses damaged by the storm were declared uninhabitable.

children.name: unfit for human habitation
children.definition: not suitable for people to live in, especially because of being dirty, cold, or wet - used especially in official contexts:
examples: The court was told that Blake had charged hundreds of dollars in rent for rooms that were unfit for human habitation.
In the 1960s, the flats were declared unfit for human habitation and demolished.

children.name: to stay in sb’s house or at a hotel
stay
children.definition: to spend a few days, weeks etc at sb else’s house or at a hotel, but not live there permanently: ởlại
examples: Where in New Hampshire were you staying?
How long are you staying?

children.name: stay (for) a few months/ two weeks etc
examples: I was having such a good time in Paris that I phoned my mother to say I was staying another week.

children.name: stay at/ in
examples: I stayed at my brother’s house for a couple of weeks.
Which hotel are you staying at?

children.name: stay withstay at sb’s house
examples: You could stay with John and Anne while you’re in London.

children.name: stay the night/ stay over/ stay overnightUK sleep at someone else’s house
examples: Is it all right if I stay the night?
You can stay over, Gail, if it would help.

children.name: come to stay
examples: One of Sarah’s friends is coming to stay with us this summer.

children.name: visit
children.definition: /visit withUS  to go to the house of a friend or relative and stay there for some time, because you want to see them: thăm hỏi
examples: I went to visit her last winter and I really had a great time.
How much do you visit with your Mom and Dad while you’re here?
So are you just visiting friends out here or something?
She sent me some photographs of when she visited in December.

children.name: board
children.definition: to stay in a room in a family house or in a house where other people have rooms, and where some or all of your meals are provided: nội trú
examples: Phoebe boards here during the week and goes home at weekends.

children.name: board with
examples: I boarded with the Jansens until I found a place of my own.
During his stay in England he boardedwitha family in Bath.

children.name: lodge
children.definition: UK if youlodge insb’s house or in a hotel, you pay money to stay there: trọ

children.name: lodge in/at/with
examples: Mrs Gould and her niece are lodging in the Rising Sun.
His wife and kids were forced to lodge with friends until they found a place of their own.
She lodgedwithMrs Higgins when she first came to Cambridge.

children.name: house-sit
children.definition: to stay in someone's house while they are away in order to keep it safe
examples: housesitter[ C ]
house-sitting[ U ]

children.name: the time when you stay swh
stay
children.definition: a limited time of living in a place, , for example when you go somewhere on holiday or for business: thời gian ở lại

children.name: a long stay
examples: During his long stay in the south, he painted only one portrait.

children.name: a short/brief stay
examples: No visa is required for short stays.

children.name: an overnight stay
examples: Business trips may involve an overnight stay.

children.name: a pleasant/enjoyable stay
examples: Our driver said goodbye and wished us a pleasant stay.

children.name: a hospital stay
children.definition: alsoa stay in hospitalBritish English,a stay in the hospitalAmerican English
examples: Sally is back at work after a short stay in hospital.

children.name: have a nice/pleasant etc stay
examples: We hope you have a pleasant stay.

children.name: extend/prolong your stay
children.definition: stay longer
examples: He could not be persuaded to extend his stay.

children.name: stay in/at
examples: I met her towards the end of my stay in Los Angeles.

children.name: live
children.definition: to have your home in a particular place:
examples: Where do you live?

children.name: live in
examples: Do you like living in Tokyo?
Judy lives in that nice house on the corner.
How do you like living in the city again after so many years away from it?

children.name: live inlive at the place where you work or study British
examples: Many students prefer to live in during their first year of study.

children.name: live at
examples: In 1905 Russell was living at 4 Ralston Street.

children.name: live at hometo live in your parents’ house
examples: Donald is 30 years old, but he still lives at home.

children.name: live abroadlive in a foreign country
examples: They lived abroad for several years but moved back when the children were school age.

children.name: grow up
children.definition: to live in a place during the time when you are a child: lớn lên
examples: This is the neighborhood where my father grew up.

children.name: grow up in
examples: Margaret Hallworth was born in Manchester but grew up in North Wales.

children.name: grow up on
examples: I grew up on a farm in eastern Pennsylvania.

children.name: be from
children.definition: especially spoken use this to talk about the place where you live:
examples: My name’s Sharon and I’m from Harlow.
The man is believed to be from somewhere in the north of England.
Where are you from?

children.name: reside
children.definition: to live in a country, city, or area - used in official contexts:

children.name: reside in
examples: Miss Badu grew up in Dallas but now resides in Brooklyn.
At that time there were many American writers residing in Paris.

children.name: reside at
examples: Miss Tonelli, how exactly did you come to reside at your current address?

children.name: reside abroadlive in a foreign country
examples: The government bureau has prepared a booklet for U.S. citizens residing abroad.

children.name: inhabit
children.definition: if a group of people or animals inhabit an area of land, they live there, especially over a long period of time or permanently - used especially in reports and written contexts: ở, sống ở (nơi nào)
examples: The island is mainly inhabited by sheep.
Some tribes still inhabit the more remote mountains and jungles of the country.
These remote islands are inhabited only by birds.

children.name: be populated by
children.definition: if an area of land is populated by a particular type of people or animals, they are the people or animals who live there: sinh sống
examples: This area of Antarctica is populated only by seals and penguins.

children.name: be heavily populated byto have a large number of a particular group
examples: Mindanao is an island in the southern Philippines heavily populated by Muslims.

children.name: resident
children.definition: living in a place

children.name: resident in
examples: Many retired British people are now resident in Spain.
She's resident abroad/inMoscow.

children.name: settle down
children.definition: to start living in a place where you intend to stay for a long time, usually with your partner: ổn định cuộc sống
examples: Eventually I'd like to settle down and have a family, but not yet.
